summary_of_threads_started_this_week:
Antoine Poinsot and the Bitcoin Core team have disclosed a vulnerability within Bitcoin Core versions prior to 25.0, alongside announcing a new security policy aimed at enhancing transparency and security through regular updates on potential system vulnerabilities. Full details of the disclosed vulnerability and the new policy can be found on [Bitcoin Core's website](https://bitcoincore.org/en/2024/09/18/disclose-headers-oom) and their [security advisories page](https://bitcoincore.org/en/security-advisories/policy), respectively.

Ava Chow highlighted the availability of Bitcoin Core version v28.0rc2 binaries, marking a significant step towards the final release of this new major version, with details and preliminary release notes accessible on [Bitcoin Core's official website](https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-28.0/test.rc2) and [GitHub](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/tree/v28.0rc2). This update signifies the release candidate stage, crucial for rigorous testing and final adjustments before the official launch.

ZmnSCPxj presented the SuperScalar mechanism, a novel construction for efficient offchain liquidity allocation in the Bitcoin Lightning Network, which utilizes Decker-Wattenhofer decrementing-`nSequence` mechanisms, timeout trees, and laddering strategies to address the Last-Mile Problem (LMP) without blockchain consensus changes. More in-depth discussion on this mechanism and its implications for the Lightning Network can be explored at [DelvingBitcoin.org](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/superscalar-laddered-timeout-tree-structured-decker-wattenhofer-factories/1143).

Finally, halseth introduced the `utxozkp` tool, advancing privacy in Lightning Network channel announcements by enabling zero-knowledge proof of UTXO set inclusion. This development not only enhances privacy but also serves as a potential anti-DOS mechanism. The tool, based on the RISC Zero STARK platform and the Utreexo data structure, is still in its early stages, with details available for review on [GitHub](https://github.com/halseth/utxozkp/blob/c3402a72005d8d1058f758ed277df9e6cafcac72/README.md).

new_threads_this_week.title: Public disclosure of 1 vulnerability affecting Bitcoin Core <24.0.1
new_threads_this_week.summary:
- The Bitcoin Core team disclosed a new vulnerability at bitcoincore.org.
- A new policy for disclosing security issues is now detailed online.
- Future updates will address pre-25.0 version vulnerabilities next month.

new_threads_this_week.title: Bitcoin Core 28.0 Release Candidate 2 Available
new_threads_this_week.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version v28.0rc2 binaries are now available for download.
- Preliminary release notes outline enhancements, fixes, and notable changes for the final version.
- If no significant issues arise, v28.0rc2 will officially become version 28.0.

new_threads_this_week.title: SuperScalar: Laddered Timeout-Tree-Structured Decker-Wattenhofer Factories
new_threads_this_week.summary:
- The SuperScalar mechanism enhances the Bitcoin Lightning Network by enabling efficient, offchain liquidity allocation.
- It utilizes Decker-Wattenhofer mechanisms, timeout trees, and laddering strategies for security and scalability.
- Practical implementation focuses on incentivizing user online presence and balancing update efficiency with exit costs.

new_threads_this_week.title: Proving UTXO set inclusion in zero-knowledge
new_threads_this_week.summary:
- The `utxozkp` tool enhances Lightning Network privacy with zero-knowledge UTXO set proofs.
- It's in early stages, taking 6 minutes to generate a 1.4 MB proof on an Apple M1 Max.
- Future updates will improve functionality, with the project welcoming community feedback.

new_threads_this_week.title: Hybrid Jamming Mitigation: Results and Updates
new_threads_this_week.summary:
- The blog post reviews a study on improving lightning channel resilience against jamming attacks.
- It details the mitigation strategy's success in various attack scenarios without economic harm.
- The strategy includes a bidirectional reputation system to enhance defense against sophisticated attacks.

active_posts_this_week.title: Adding New BIP Editors
active_posts_this_week.summary:
- The draft aims to streamline the BIP process, proposing changes such as eliminating the comments system.
- Key changes include reducing status values, introducing a "Specification" BIP type, and making Process BIPs living documents.
- It suggests less involvement of BIP Editors in decisions, pushing for more decentralized decision-making processes.

active_posts_this_week.title: PPLNS with job declaration
active_posts_this_week.summary:
- The recent graph modifications clarified the delta steps on the MMEF axis.
- This change improves viewers' understanding of the process by providing a clearer visual representation.
- It significantly aids in comprehending the mechanism in the context of PPLNS with Job Declaration.

active_posts_this_week.title: Who will run the CoinJoin coordinators?
active_posts_this_week.summary:
- Adam Gibson discusses Joinmarket's central communication issues compared to Coinshuffle.
- A "directory node" via .onion services was introduced to improve decentralization and privacy.
- Despite facilitating larger P2P coinjoin transactions, the approach underperforms Coinshuffle in privacy.

active_posts_this_week.title: Privately sending payments while offline with BOLT12
active_posts_this_week.summary:
- The proposal aims to standardize secure remote communication between controls and high-uptime home nodes.
- It focuses on enhancing security and ease of use by enabling pairing with hardware wallets.
- Standardizing control messages aims to improve user experience in the Bitcoin Lightning Network.

active_posts_this_week.title: Modeling (Social) Consensus About (Cryptographic) Consensus Change
active_posts_this_week.summary:
- Exploring consensus changes in Bitcoin highlights significant challenges and time requirements.
- Karl Popper's falsification theory is applied to evaluate blockchain consensus change processes.
- The adoption of MAST into Bitcoin after eight years exemplifies the ossification of consensus rules.
